Issues.Title: Unstable unit test: System.Windows.Forms.Tests.RadioButtonRendererTests.RadioButtonRenderer_DrawRadioButton_OverloadWithHandle
Issues.Body:
### Test

System.Windows.Forms.Tests.RadioButtonRendererTests.RadioButtonRenderer_DrawRadioButton_OverloadWithHandle(focus: True)

### Issue description

**Error Message:**

- **In X86 unit:**
     System.InvalidOperationException : Invalid handle (0)

- **Stack trace:**

```
   at Windows.Win32.Graphics.Gdi.DeviceContextHdcScope.ValidateHDC() in /_/src/System.Private.Windows.GdiPlus/Windows/Win32/Graphics/Gdi/DeviceContextHdcScope.cs:line 186
   at Windows.Win32.Graphics.Gdi.DeviceContextHdcScope..ctor(IHdcContext deviceContext, ApplyGraphicsProperties applyGraphicsState, Boolean saveHdcState) in /_/src/System.Private.Windows.GdiPlus/Windows/Win32/Graphics/Gdi/DeviceContextHdcScope.cs:line 147
   at System.Windows.Forms.DeviceContextExtensions.ToHdcScope(IDeviceContext deviceContext, ApplyGraphicsProperties applyProperties) in /_/src/System.Windows.Forms.Primitives/src/System/Windows/Forms/DeviceContextExtensions.cs:line 184
   at System.Windows.Forms.TextRenderer.DrawTextInternal(IDeviceContext dc, ReadOnlySpan`1 text, Font font, Rectangle bounds, Color foreColor, Color backColor, TextFormatFlags flags) in /_/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Rendering/TextRenderer.cs:line 307
   at System.Windows.Forms.TextRenderer.DrawText(IDeviceContext dc, String text, Font font, Rectangle bounds, Color foreColor, TextFormatFlags flags) in /_/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Rendering/TextRenderer.cs:line 205
   at System.Windows.Forms.RadioButtonRenderer.DrawRadioButton(Graphics g, Point glyphLocation, Rectangle textBounds, String radioButtonText, Font font, TextFormatFlags flags, Boolean focused, RadioButtonState state, HWND hwnd) in /_/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Controls/Buttons/RadioButtonRenderer.cs:line 147
   at System.Windows.Forms.Tests.RadioButtonRendererTests.RadioButtonRenderer_DrawRadioButton_OverloadWithHandle(Boolean focus) in /_/src/System.Windows.Forms/tests/UnitTests/System/Windows/Forms/RadioButtonRendererTests.cs:line 118
   at System.RuntimeMethodHandle.InvokeMethod(ObjectHandleOnStack target, Void** arguments, ObjectHandleOnStack sig, BOOL isConstructor, ObjectHandleOnStack result)
   at System.Reflection.MethodBaseInvoker.InvokeDirectByRefWithFewArgs(Object obj, Span`1 copyOfArgs, BindingFlags invokeAttr)
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Unstable unit test: System.Windows.Forms.Tests.RadioButtonRendererTests.RadioButtonRenderer_DrawRadioButton_OverloadWithHandle" (#12935)

Issues.Title: Can't show a message box in the DataGridView RowValidating event for a newly added row because it will result in more errors when CancelNew is called
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

8.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

no

### Issue description

Can't show a message box in the DataGridView RowValidating event for a newly added row because it will result in more errors when CancelNew is called

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add RowValidating event to the DataGridView that will show a meesage box when validation fails
2. In a new row enter invalid data
3. Try to move to another row to start validation
4. Message box is shown
5. Press Escape key to cancel new row
6. Error message (IndexOutOfRangeException) is shown multple times

Error message (IndexOutOfRangeException) isn't shown when message box isn't shown in the RowValidating event

[TestDGVGetError.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/18766788/TestDGVGetError.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Can't show a message box in the DataGridView RowValidating event for a newly added row because it will result in more errors when CancelNew is called" (#12926)

Issues.Title: Illegal use of Unsafe.Unbox<T> in PropertyStore.cs
Issues.Body:
(Found via static analysis.)

The use of `Unsafe.Unbox<T>` in two lines

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/7210b61063d105d1cc2642682955aed6c03fef43/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/PropertyStore.cs#L217-L218

is not a legal operation and could destabilize the runtime. Please do not assign values to the `T&` returned by `Unsafe.Unbox<T>`. See the _Remarks_ section of https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/api/system.runtime.compilerservices.unsafe.unbox for more information.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Illegal use of Unsafe.Unbox<T> in PropertyStore.cs" (#12933)

Issues.Title: [dnceng-bot] Branch `winforms/release/8.0` can't be merged to Azdo internal branch
Issues.Body:
Branch [release/8.0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/commits/release/8.0/) in `dotnet/winforms` repo can't be mirrored from GitHub to Azure [internal/release/8.0](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_git/dotnet-winforms?version=GBinternal%2Frelease%2F8.0&_a=history) via internal merge. 

There are conflicting commits in the target branch.
The branch is configured to be mirrored via automated merge. 
The situation is rare but normal. The target branch is expected to receive manual commits in the Azure DevOps clone, which could cause conflict.

Conflicts need to be **resolved to unblock the code flow**.

- you can resolve the issue by resolving the conflict in the **target branch only**. 
    - Please make sure that the changes sensitive from security perspective are not published ahead of time to GitHub!
- reverting the extra commits in the Azdo target branch.
- checking the logs of the mirroring process in the [mirroring pipeline](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_build?definitionId=1387).
- you can disable the mirroring of the branch in the [configuration file](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_git/dotnet-mirroring?path=/dnceng-subscriptions.jsonc).
- you can ask @dotnet/dnceng for help or read the [documentation](https://dev.azure.com/dnceng/internal/_git/dotnet-mirroring?path=/README.md).

Please close this issue once the conflict is resolved.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[dnceng-bot] Branch `winforms/release/8.0` can't be merged to Azdo internal branch" (#12932)

Issues.Title: Ensure typed deserialization requires exact type match from resolver
Issues.Body: Need to validate at the lowest level in BinaryFormatUtilities. Currently this is not blocked. You should not be able to ask for a base type without a resolver to get derived types.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ensure typed deserialization requires exact type match from resolver" (#12929)

Issues.Title: Ensure Json serialized data can be read from any API
Issues.Body:
Writing as JSON should just work throughout the system. While users should move to the new typed APIs they cannot always change everything. This allows moving existing data that can be serialized as Json to the Json API and all consumers on .NET 10+ will be able to read it without changes.

Also:

- Feedback from the last PR and more documentation cleanup
- New tests directly against the NativeToManagedAdapter with IDataObject mocks
- Flip the bool on DataRequest
- Add a DisposableBase class for easy robust IDisposable support
- Move HGLOBAL Stream helper to StreamExtensions
 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/12928)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Ensure Json serialized data can be read from any API" (#12928)

Issues.Body:
Need to make sure that we test things like `Hashtable` thoroughly to make sure that we pass through instances with unsupported content and that we don't lose data over fields we don't currently handle (notably the comparer in this case).

`CoreNrbfSerializer` is the exposure point.

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[main] Update dependencies from dotnet/runtime" (#12923)

Issues.Title: More refactoring and behavior tweaks for OLE APIs.
Issues.Body:
Tweak `BinaryFormatUtilities.TryReadObjectFromStream` to:

- Not fall back to `BinaryFormatter` if we identify a fully supported type that we cannot deserialize.
- Use `TypeBinder` to check typed requests to match `BinaryFormatter` matching.
- Block `BinaryFormatter` with untyped requests that don't have an explictly provided resolver callback. Allows safe usage of other `TryGet` APIs with primitive types and JSON serialization.

Stop trying to reflect types to find `TypeForwardedFrom`.  Most of this change is in `TyeExtensions`. It doesn't reflect the way `BinaryFormatter` handles type names and makes writing binders completely different than ones provided directly to `BinaryFormatter`. Our implicit handling still works, users can rely on ours for primitives (see below) or handle the actual incoming names.

Change binder `Func` to return `Type?`. Users should throw to block types from resolving, or return `null` to allow us to make the decision for them. We block all types that are not `IsFullySupportedType` in our core `TypeBinder` class. `TypeBinder` also rejects auto binding to root types that are `object` or `interface`.

Change `INrbfDecoder.IsSupportedType` to `IsFullySupportedType`. Method should describe types we expect to be fully able to deserialize manually. See docs for full details.

Change `DataFormatNames.IsRestrictedFormat` to `IsPredefinedFormat` to better reflect it's meaning.

Add static methods to `IOleServices` to allow abstracting OLE access for testing. Test classes and basic patterns can be found in `ClipboardCoreTests`. Also add a factory static to allow creating a `DataObject`.

Add typed `IDataObjectInternal<TDataObject, TIDataObject>` this allows moving even more logic into Core. `DataObject` and `Clipboard` now have most logic in Core. `DataObjectCore` is now greatly simplified.

Remove `IRuntime`. This aggregation was causing more issues than it was worth. It made it possible to create inadvertant type mismatches and made writing tests more difficult.

No longer throw out of `Try` methods. It is inconsistent with other methods and creates additional risk around uncontrolled incoming data. Exceptions are still thrown externally and can be useful for debugging.

Use `ArgumentException.ThrowIfNullOrWhiteSpace` for greater simplicity and consistency.

Add another convenience define to `TypeNameComparison`: `AllButAssemblyVersion`.

Unify some BinaryFormatter utility into BinarySerialization (more needs done).

More comment polish and additional testing will come in subsequent PRs. I also plan to add more OLE mock behavior to better represent more real OLE behavior.
 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/12912)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "More refactoring and behavior tweaks for OLE APIs." (#12912)

Issues.Title: Validate and test Clipboard JSON and raw data scenarios
Issues.Body:
The new write as JSON APIs should be visible to all Clipboard/DataObject API callers (existing or new API).

- In or out of process
- With copy = true or not
- Legacy platforms with type access to `System.Text.Json` and `BinaryFormatter`

We should also be able to retrieve raw data

- Need full tests documenting legacy `MemoryStream` behavior to ensure the following points are sensible
- Asking for `<MemoryStream>` in new typed APIs should always give back the raw stream for HGLOBAL
- Asking for `<SerializationRecord>` should NRBF decode HGLOBAL data
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Validate and test Clipboard JSON and raw data scenarios" (#12919)

Issues.Title: No tooltip display for ToolStripDropDownButton after using right/Left/Enter to collapse ToolStripDropDownButton
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET SDK 10.0.100-preview2.25110.18

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Can reproduce on all previous, NET versions

### Issue description

No tooltip display for ToolStripDropDownButton after using right/Left/Enter to collapse ToolStripDropDownButton 
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/27a4b04c-8c25-478f-bfde-304230cedf51)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create Winforms .NET app with ToolStrip control 
2. Add ToolStripDropDownButton item for toolStip1, and add toolStripMenuItem for ToolStripDropDownButton  
3. Set the toolstrip1's TabStop property to True 
4. Build and run app 
5. Press down/Enter to expand ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip1 - **it will focus on toolStripMenuIteml** 
6. Press right/Left/Enter to collapse ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip1- **it will focus on ToolStripDropDownButton, but no tooltip display for ToolStripDropDownButton**  

**More info:**
The issue cannot reproduce when using Alt keyboard to collapse the ToolStripDropDownButton
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "No tooltip display for ToolStripDropDownButton after using right/Left/Enter to collapse ToolStripDropDownButton" (#12917)

Issues.Title: Cannot use  down to expand ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip2 after using right/Left to collapse ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip1
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET SDK 10.0.100-preview2.25110.18

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Can reproduce on all previous, NET versions

### Issue description

Cannot use down to expand ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip2 after using right/Left to collapse ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip1 

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create Winforms .NET app with 2 toolStrips
2. In these 2 toolStrips, add ToolStripDropDownButton, add toolStripMenuItem for ToolStripDropDownButton separately 
3. Set these 2 toolStrips' TabStop property to True 
4. Build and run app 
5. Press down to expand ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip1 - it will focus on toolStripMenuItem 
6. Press right/Left to collapse ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip1- it will focus on ToolStripDropDownButton  
7.  Tab to toolstrip2 button 
8. Press down to expand ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip2  -- it will focus on ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip1 

Or using the application & repeat the steps 4~8
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0c9769fe-2835-4ba9-8c95-ed8b35845e2c)

**More info:** 
1. The issue also can reproduce when using Enter and right keyboard combination 
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5bbb8368-3e48-45e4-a3e1-153c35d474de)
2. The issue cannot reproduce when using Enter & Enter or Enter & Alt or Down & Alt keyboard combinations
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Cannot use  down to expand ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip2 after using right/Left to collapse ToolStripDropDownButton in toolStrip1" (#12916)

Issues.Title: [release/8.0] Fix 12850 error provider exception in different dpi
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Back port pr #10850 to release8.0
Fixes #12850

## Bug Description

The PR #8486 removed `new Icon(icon, 16 ,16)` from `IconRegion` constructor, that causes the released icon object to be directly referenced,  so there is an exception `Cannot access a disposed object. Object name: 'Icon' ` of issue #12850.

## Customer Impact

- ErrorProvider exception when shown a second time after being dragged on another monitor with different DPI. This regression was reported by the customer.

## Regression? 

- Yes, it's fine in dotnet 7. This is due to #8486

## Risk

- Low - restoring the previous version of code and we had already shipped this fix in NET9

## Testing

- Manual testing
- Added Unit tests

 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/12915)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "[release/8.0] Fix 12850 error provider exception in different dpi" (#12915)

Issues.Title: Win11 24H2 .NET bug rendering text to image using GDI+
Issues.Body:
### Description

Previous to 24H2, running the same code to generate an image with text produced an identical image every time that passed a pixel-by-pixel comparison test. As of 24H2 the same images generated twice fail pixel-by-pixel comparison.

This is a .NET issue. The tests pass when I use .NET Framework 4.8.

Note: I reported this bug to Windows 11 feedback before realizing this is a .NET issue (https://aka.ms/AAuckmw).

### Reproduction Steps

Repo with code to reproduce the bug:  https://github.com/tracktownsoftware/Win11-24H2-ImageTextBug
Press the "Compare Images" button.

### Expected behavior

Expected behavior: 
- The code generates identical images every time.
- Pixel-by-pixel comparison passes (before Windows 11 version 24H2)

### Actual behavior

Actual behavior:
The same images are generated twice but fail pixel-by-pixel comparison. This started with the release of Windows 11 version 24H2.

Note: On a computer with 24H2 I changed the test app to use .NET Framework 4.8. The comparison tests passed, showing this to be a .NET issue.

### Regression?

Yes this is a regression. If you run the repo test app with a Win11 version before 24H2 then it works.

### Known Workarounds

Don't upgrade to Windows 11 to 24H2

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Win11 24H2 .NET bug rendering text to image using GDI+" (#12910)
